leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Chapter 19 is specific to appliances and systems that are not related to HVAC, including cooking appliances, sauna heaters, fuel cells and hydrogen systems. Chapter 24 also applies to cooking appliances and sauna heaters.
Code development reminder: Code change proposals to this chapter will be considered by the IRC—Plumbing/Mechanical Code Development Committee during the 2021 (Group A) Code Development Cycle.
leanCodeSectionsTree.displayTitle: Chapter 19 Special Appliances, Equipment and Systems

children.body: Freestanding or built-in ranges shall have a vertical clearance above the cooking top of not less than 30 inches (762 mm) to unprotected combustible material. Reduced clearances are permitted in accordance with the listing and labeling of the range hoods or ovens with integral exhaust.

Cooking appliances shall be listed and labeled for household use and shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. The installation shall not interfere with combustion air or access for operation and servicing. Electric cooking appliances shall comply with UL 858 or UL 1026. Solid-fuel-fired fireplace stoves shall comply with UL 737. Microwave ovens shall comply with UL 923.

diagrams.title: Residential Smoke Alarms: Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single-, multi- station smoke alarms - Smoke alarms are required to be installed within all residential occupancies. Minimally, these smoke alarms are required to be installed within each sleeping area, outside of each sleeping area, and on each floor. Additionally, the Building Code requires that a smoke alarm be installed in every room in the path of egress for R-1 occupancies. Smoke alarms are required to be interconnected, whereas, when one activates, all smoke alarms sound. Smoke alarms are not to be installed within 3 feet of a bathroom. Smoke alarm installation exceptions apply in regards to cooking equipment.

diagrams.title: Vertical Clearance above Cooking Top
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent combustible materials over a cooking top from igniting the code requires at least 30" of vertical clearance from the top of the cooking top to any combustible materials directly above a cooking top. Under certain conditions the vertical clearance may be reduced to 24". The vertical clearance may be reduced to 24" when a 1/4 inch insulating millboard covered with sheet metal not less than 0.0122 inch thick protection is applied to the underside of the combustible material above. When an exhaust hood fabricated of sheet metal not less than 0.0122 inches thick is installed with a 1/4" vertical gap to combustible material above the hood is installed over the cooking top, the bottom of the hood may not be less than 24" above the cooking top. When the cooking top is listed and above a listed cooking appliance or microwave oven is installed per the manufacturer's instructions, the bottom of the upper appliance may not be less than 24" above the cooking top.

children.body: Sauna heaters shall be protected from accidental contact by persons with a guard of material having a low thermal conductivity, such as wood. The guard shall not have a substantial effect on the transfer of heat from the heater to the room.
Sauna heaters shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Sauna heaters shall comply with UL 875.
Combustion air and venting for a nondirect vent-type heater shall be provided in accordance with Chapters 17 and 18, respectively.

Sauna heaters shall be equipped with a thermostat that will limit room temperature to not greater than 194°F (90°C). Where the thermostat is not an integral part of the heater, the heat-sensing element shall be located within 6 inches (152 mm) of the ceiling.

children.displayTitle: Section M1903 Stationary Fuel Cell Power Plants

children.body: Stationary fuel cell power plants having a power output not exceeding 1,000 kW shall comply with ANSI/CSA America FC 1 and shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and NFPA 853.

Gaseous hydrogen systems shall be installed in accordance with the applicable requirements of Sections M1307.4 and M1903.1, the South Carolina Building Code, the South Carolina Fire Code and the South Carolina Fuel Gas Code.
